titleInfo.title: Geology and Structural Interpretations of the Abanda Fault and the Jackson's Gap Group, within Alabama

name.namePart: Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Science

mods:mods.abstract: The Jackson's Gap Group is a thin section (~3 km wide) of sheared, compositionally interlayered metamorphic rocks spanning from west Georgia to central Alabama, representing the southernmost extent of the Brevard Zone. The lithostratigraphic units within the Jackson's Gap Group are predominately muscovite and garnetiferous schists ranging from graphitic to non-graphitic, which are interlayed with clean and micaceous quartzites and minor metaigneous units. Within the western limb of the Tallassee synform, the Jackson's Gap Group is separated from the underlying Emuckfaw Group by the Abanda fault and the overlying Dadeville complex by the Katy Creek Fault. The Kowaliga Gneiss is an Ordovician plutonic body that intruded the stratigraphic boundary between the Emuckfaw Group and the Jackson's Gap Group, resulting in augen gneiss sills intruding and paralleling the oldest portion of the Jackson's Gap stratigraphy. This intrusional boundary suggests the protoliths of the Jackson's Gap Group were deposited within closer proximity to the Wedowee-Emuckfaw-Dahlonega back-arc basin than previously thought. Additionally, the metaigneous units within the Jackson's Gap Group further its association with the Ordovician back-arc system related to the current B-type supra-subduction model of the Taconic Orogeny responsible for formation the southern Appalachians. Within the study area, a cataclastic zone associated with the Abanda fault, around 10 meters thick, contains a wide range of cataclastic rocks that indicate multiple stages of reactivation and cataclasis. Both identified Abanda cataclastic splays do not offset any surrounding Ordovician-Silurian units within the Emuckfaw and Jackson's Gap Groups. Based on these cataclastic rocks and a proposed Abanda fault outcrop, the nature of the Abanda fault differs from previous conclusions and tips out around the town of Jackson's Gap, Alabama.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Abanda Fault, Alabama, Brevard Zone, Jackson's Gap Group, Taconic Orogeny, Tallassee Synform
James F. Tull, Professor Directing Thesis; Seth Young, Committee Member; Emily Stewart, Committee Member.
